case_vignette: A 14-year-old boy presents with a 1-month history of gradual onset of pain immediately below his right kneecap. He has recently started playing basketball for the junior varsity team at his school, and he is very excited for the season to begin. Unfortunately, the pain in his knee is exacerbated by all the jumping activity during practice. The patient reports similar pain when climbing up and down the stairs. He denies any previous history of knee injury. Physical examination reveals full range of motion of his knee, but the pain is reproduced when the knee is extended against resistance.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having pain right below my right kneecap for a month, which gets worse when I play basketball and when I go up and down stairs.
How old are you?
I'm 14 years old.
Are you male or female?
I'm a boy.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your knee?
No, I haven't had any previous knee injuries.
Do you see any swelling, redness, or feel warmth around your knee?
No, there's no swelling, redness, or warmth.
Is the pain localized to one specific area below the kneecap, or does it spread out?
The pain is right below my kneecap.
Does your knee ever give way, lock, or feel unstable?
No, it doesn't.
Have you noticed any popping or clicking sounds when your knee pain occurs?
I didn't mention anything about popping or clicking sounds, just the pain.
Understood. Do you participate in any activities that involve a lot of jumping or running?
Yes, I recently started playing basketball for the junior varsity team at my school.
Is the pain in your knee relieved by rest, or is it constant regardless of activity level?
The pain gets worse with jumping activity during basketball practice and when climbing stairs, but you didn't ask about rest specifically.
Does the pain improve when you rest?
I didn't say anything about the pain improving with rest.
Do any members of your family have a history of joint or knee problems?
I haven't mentioned any family history of joint or knee problems.
Final Diagnosis: Osgood-Schlatter disease.
